body:
So we had various discussions about this amongst the core team.

In 13b3c77e393b8fb02588f39e6bfa10c832e251ff I have added `Relation#find_by` and `Relation#find_by!` to provide this sort of functionality.

In terms of deprecating dynamic finders, it was felt that the single-column variant should definitely stay:

``` ruby
Person.find_by_name('Jon')
```

Of course, if we only did that we wouldn't need to use `method_missing`, we could just define the `find_by_` methods when all the other attribute methods get defined.

However, David was keen to keep the multi-column variant also:

``` ruby
Person.find_by_first_name_and_last_name('Jon', 'Leighton')
```

I personally don't agree that that is nicer than:

``` ruby
Person.find_by first_name: 'Jon', last_name: 'Leighton'
```

But for the moment, `find_by_*` and `find_by_*!` will stay.

It was however agreed to deprecate all the other dynamic finder variants:

* `find_or_initialize_by_*`
* `find_or_create_by_*`
* `find_all_by_*`
* `find_last_by_*`
* `scoped_by_*`

These will be extracted into a plugin to make upgrading less painful.
